action.action-desc: Mr. Trone (for himself and Mr. Meuser) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To establish a grant program for family community organizations that provide support for individuals struggling with substance use disorder and their families.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Supporting Families through Addiction Act of 2023.

section.header: Family support services for families of individuals struggling with substance use disorder
section.text: Part D of title V of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 290dd et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Family support services for families of individuals struggling with substance use disorder

paragraph.text: the term family community organization means an independent nonprofit organization that—

subparagraph.text: mobilizes resources within and outside of the community of families that include an individual living with a substance use disorder, to provide a support network, education, and evidence-informed tools for families and loved ones of individuals struggling with substance use disorders; and
is governed by experts in the field of substance use disorder, which may include—

clause.text: experts in evidence-informed interventions for family members;
experts in the impact of substance use disorder on family systems;
families who have experience with substance use disorder; and
other experts in the field of substance use disorder; and

paragraph.text: the term family support services means resources or programs that support families that include an individual with substance use disorder.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall award grants to family community organizations to enable such organizations to develop, expand, and enhance evidence-informed family support services.
The Federal share of the costs of a program funded by a grant under this section may not exceed 85 percent.

paragraph.text: shall be used to develop, expand, and enhance community, Tribal, and statewide evidence-informed family support services; and

subparagraph.text: build connections between family support networks, including providing technical assistance between family community organizations and peer support networks, and with other family support services, focused on enhancing knowledge of evidence-informed interventions for family members and loved ones of individuals living with substance use disorders and reducing harm by educating service providers on current evidence regarding substance use disorder and the family, including—

clause.text: behavioral health providers, including such providers focused specifically on family and couples therapy in the context of substance use disorder;
providers of foster care services or support services for grandparents, guardians, and other extended family impacted by substance use disorder; and
other family support services that connect to community resources for individuals with substance use disorders, including non-clinical community services;

subparagraph.text: reduce stigma associated with families that include an individual with a substance use disorder by improving knowledge about substance use disorder and its treatment, providing compassionate support, and dispelling myths that perpetuate such stigma;
conduct outreach on issues relating to substance use disorders and family support, which may include education, training, and resources with respect to—

clause.text: building a resilience- and strengths-based approach to prevention of, and living with, substance use disorder in the family;
identifying the signs of substance use disorder;
adopting an approach that minimizes harm to all family members; and
families that include an individual with a substance use disorder, including with respect to—

subclause.text: navigating the treatment and recovery systems;
paying for substance use disorder treatment;
education about substance use disorder; and

subparagraph.text: connect families to evidence-informed peer support programs.

subsection.text: With respect to a grant awarded under subsection (a), not later than 90 days after the end of the first year of the grant period, and annually thereafter for the duration of the grant period, the entity shall submit data, as appropriate and to the extent practicable, to the Secretary regarding—

paragraph.text: the programs and activities funded by the grant;

outcomes for the families of individuals with a substance use disorder who received services through programs supported by the grant, as evaluated by an independent program evaluator through the use of outcomes measures, as determined by the Secretary; and
any other information that the Secretary may require for the purpose of ensuring that the grant recipient is complying with all the requirements of the grant.

subsection.text: There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section $5,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2024 through 2028.
